his theory is that we should try our hand on non-monogamy. since human
beings (mostly men) have different sexual urges than their partners,
their partners should allow them to pursue those desires, maybe it
would be for the better.
i'm a realist. and looking at the current gossip world of sex scandals
being uncovered one after another, i must say there is some truth to
what he says.
and instead of outright saying all these men are bastards, maybe we
should just lower our standards and instead think of ways to avoid
them.
so there's a thought. but important thing. failing at monogamy is not
succeeding at non-monogamy.

i've joked about amy chua a lot, saying my mom is a lot like her. well
the following are three articles that i think are representative of
the asian-american case
1) http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2011/04/the-ivy-delusion/8397/?single_page=true
asian mothers, i.e. amy chua, are willing to give up their child's
childhood to get into a elite college. and western mothers don't agree
because of psychological reasons and what not. the truth is that
western mothers know that asians are taking the spots of their own
kids.

2) http://nymag.com/news/features/asian-americans-2011-5/
asian kids get into elite colleges. they have the highest median
salary of any ethnicity. but they don't rise to the top. at heart, we
are still afraid.

3) http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424053111904233404576462042857022426.html
the reality holds that, maybe because of some underlying racism, or
simply a problem with the asian mentality, we never rise to the top.

4) http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2011/04/sympathy-for-the-tiger-moms/8399/
a sort of recap on this asian-american life. we have our highs when we
are young, but in our 40's we are all fallen prodigies, who have given
up for other things. in the end, she makes a good point. we may be
prodigies now, but "in a century, no one will be humming us." i think
i should too just do something i like, lead a life i like, so that we
may not have success, but we have content.
